comments.commentBody: When I and several others were newbie professors we had to endure trial by older professor. Most of these old guys (and I do mean guys - all of them were old men) admitted that the only way they would ever leave the department was in a box. These guys used thier own biases to judge our teaching and spent many an hour dragging us through the coals. The result was that all the new faculty ended up quitting and the old geezers were left to themselves. Don't ever think that older professors are THE answer to teacher evaluation.

This is not a numbers game: 'Real Growth' is a buzzword collection and illusion. Without floods of inexpensive energy, there is no growth. Yhe GDP numbers are fraudulent, counting money taken from the left pocket and put into the right.

This is not a dilemma but a predicament: Both approaches have the same outcome- depression. We have leveraged everything to machine production on one hand and forced consumption on the other. There is no return on either. The establishment stimulates the economy with little to show for it. The cost of the stimulus bankrupts the establishment. What is 'Plan B'?

This is not a repeat of crises past: It IS different this time! We have run out of cheap energy. Any sort of 'reform' that does not include stringent conservation is doomed to fail. Failure is permanent; that means there will be no 'recovery' in any time span that is meaningful to the human race.

This is not a drill; This is the end of the war between humans and the automobile. We have remade our world to satisfy the needs of the conquerer and the consequence is ruin. The auto and its unquenchable thirst will leave the human race stranded along the side of the useless multi- trillion dollar auto- infrastructure gas cans in hand.

It's conserve or die, that simple.
Maybe we should give the reins back to the Republicans and let them drive the economy off the cliff. With a spectacular bust like that we should be all set for the next bubble!

I wouldn't bet on the private sector to help out the problem we Americans have with finding jobs. While looking for a job, I have been told over and over again by small businesses, " when the recession is over-you will leave us; why should I waste all that time on hiring you"? I can't contribute to the economy in a positive way if I do not have a job.

I'm pleased to see that about 30-40% of the comments are now brazenly disputing the NY Times desperately clinging to Keynesian logic. This gives me hope.

Murray Rothbard accurately portrayed fiat based money systems as theft. Is it any surprise that when the public has been robbed by their banks and government of their wealth that the economy goes in to a depression?

We must return the people's gold that was confiscated during the Great Depression, and then use gold as an untaxed competing currency. If people are as confident in the dollar when they can use gold instead, then we will have price stability and recovery.

This is absolutely laughable. The Democrats, once again, show what they're made of - weakness. We, as a nation, are at a point where we'd be better off if the Republicans held all branches of government and then proceeded to take the whole country down with them. We'd have to start all over again, but it would be better than this slow bleeding to death.

There have been other articles by liberal columnists (see Paul Krugman) claiming that this push for "austerity" will repeat the mistakes of 1937 and lead us to another recession or depression.  But none of these articles ever provide any data on the relative size of the budget deficit and government debt to GDP today vs. 1937.  The reality is that even with all this talk of "austerity", the U.S. and all the other major economies will be running budget deficits for years, in the range of hundreds of billions to trillions of dollars.  Doesn't this count at all as "government stimulus"?  So why all the panic from the liberal press and the NY Times when all we are really talking about is taking the first small steps back to fiscal sanity?
So...exactly what part of "relying on the private sector" sounds reasonable after what we've experienced the last few decades?

What would Reagan do?

Per the NYTimes, after 1982 we had five straight quarters with annualized growth of 7% to 9%. How did that happen? Can't we do that again?

Private needs Public funding. WPA worked before, but the very smart college boys in the cabinet who run the show now, seem to have been home sick when it was studied in their school days.

Electric power grid, Hoover Dam, Man to the Moon, Interstate highway, TVA etc.

We got modern infrastructure systems and it put 10's of millions to work.

Its just too simple. But we like to talk and talk and talk about deficits, taxes , inflation , currency value............just shut up and start building a new modern country.

The article mentions congressional Republicans, but fails to point out the main reason for all the hype about cutting debt NOW--the fact that if Obama had just a little more elbow room the economy would likely recover smartly, thereby dooming Republican chances in 2010 and 2012. The Republicans want the economy to sputter and slump--and they will then blame debt, despite the deflation. Keynesian economics is still poorly understood, especially by the masses of American voters who imagine that running the world's largest economy is just like running their households.

Cutting spending will not curb the deficit; taxes must be cut as well.  When taxes are lowered, revenue increases.  Why can't liberals accept that fact?  Even many European countries are beginning to figure it out.

Well, Massachusetts voters- did you see this one coming? I bet you didn't. Scratch a Republican, find a corporate lackey underneath. That will teach you to vote for a lightweight centerfold guy. He just got bought by the banks. The best government crooked corporate money can buy.
Now banks won't have to pay the tax. The taxpayers will pay it for them.

What is really astonishing is that anyone takes this Keynesian hogwash seriously.

Wealth means goods and services, not bookkeeping entries. Wealth is created by production, not by consumption. The facilities that make wealth possible exist because of saving, not spending. And every dollar spent by the government is a dollar not spent by the private entity that the dollar was borrowed or taxed from.

It would be a great thing if economists whose theories denied these facts were treated as the quacks they are rather than our sole guardians against economic calamity.

As in past recessions, if we let the markets clear out the inefective and inefficient activities, letting the economy spend a little time scraping along a stablized bottom, then the economy would have a chance to come back. It is amazing the economic activity unleased by a free people who have confidence in their future.

I've been a glass is full optimist all my life. My confidence in the future, for the first time in my life, is shattered. I work two jobs & I am doing well, but this is what I see: a government that every few days announces a shocking new direction; creeping higher taxes as far as the eye can see to match higher deficit spending as far as the eye can see; financial regulation reform that won't work in an era of "financial innovation" that can produce new, unexpected problems; an unknown change to our health care system, where cost will continue to rise and future innovation, that could improve our lives, is in question; a volitile environment in Iraq where it is possible civil war can break out among the three ethnic groups as our troops leave; widening into a larger Mid-east conflict; a growing war in Afghanistan that increasingly resembles Vietnam, with an enemy that can take refuge across a border we can't cross; Iran, clearing building a nuclear weapon, and delaying “talking” as it makes progress towards it goal & the lack of resolve to stop a rogue state like Iran; the media giving a voice to those that want to end Israel; a large trade deficit that has transfered US wealth oversea; China a large investor in US Treasury obligations, which gives them negotiating power for the first time over the US; the very real possible diminishing capacity of the US military because of the rising social obligations of the Federal govenment, as has happended with Europe; if the US loses its superpower hold on the world, who will step in and fill the void; will they, as it will probably be more than one nation, be as benevolet as the US; will we, as a result, have World Wars; the free trade agreements that benenfit many US citizens but leave many behind, including many non-college oriented new graduates; the free trade agreements that served as a catalyst for US corporations to transfer technology overseas, creating competitors, some with questionable long term motives towards our security; the dismantling of NASA and US human deep space travel plans.
All of these are the significant risk ahead that have diminished my confidence. And the list keeps growing, and the items in it gaining in intensity.

I am ignorant and admit it. For some reaon, I always thought Ireland had a high unemployment rate with a bunch of "over educated citizens". I am not being sarcastic. From my knowledge Ireland repects Education. Can someone please explain how a 7.9% unemployment rate is so bad as I always thought it was worse. I always thought this is why there are so many Irish nannys and Irish bartenders in NYC and on the other side of the spectrum a lot of Irish are buying apts in NYC.

All of the megacorporations - banking, finance, petrochemical, pharmaceutical, defense, healthcare - have bled the consumer (and the taxpayer) dry with the consequences of their lust for record-breaking profits and their risk-taking behaviors; and now, they're just standing back while the world collapses?

As I read this article, Ireland could weather its problems if credit for infrastructure projects, and other job creation efforts were extended - but no one is willing to take on the financial risk of loaning. a. country. money. (As if the country's going to sneak away in the night and change addresses or phone numbers.)

Financial institutions are OK about taking taxpayer money to shore up their shareholders... OK about having unlimited influence in political campaigns... OK at getting favors from legislators... but they balk at taking on more of a stakeholder position within their communities, states, countries, or of cutting their hideous profits, or being accountable for their failures at all.

As Franklin said, either we all hang together - or we hang separately. Even global corporations; I hope they keep in mind who buys their products (the "little people") and act in everyone's best interests by allowing us the luxury of earning a living sufficient to buy their wares.

Otherwise, they're not unlike the neighborhood protection racket.

the only true recovery will be a private sector recovery.
anything else is just a taxpayer funded attempt to buy votes.

A cardinal rule in economics is governments not raise taxes during a recession of period of economic weakness. George H. W. ("No new taxes, read my lips") Bush painfully learned this lesson (including failure to keep major campaign promises) when the economy was thrown into a recession by his signing onto the Democrat tax increase and his later being defeated by Bill Clinton in the presidential election ("It's the economy, stupid").

President Obama and his Democrat Congressional members so far do not seem to have gotten this no new taxes during trying economic times. With unemployment hovering just under 10% and some forecasters suggesting it may return to double digits soon and with plans to tax the foreign profits of US multinationals, sharply raise taxes on corporate dividends and capital gains, it seems the administration is taking all the right steps to guarantee a double dip recession or worse. Krugman has warned about a type of depression on the way. He wants more government stimulus but the answer, which has repeatedly worked to stimulate the private sector, to lift the economy and generate new jobs is across the board tax cuts. To do this, government will need to work harder to get lean and mean rather than tax and spend. The current massive stimulus program has failed to create permanent or long term jobs in the private sector. If the government is to pump more money into the economy, let it be for alternative energy and mass transit that will reduce the costs to our economy for imported energy while actually creating a large number of white collar, professional and skilled worker jobs.

"Cutting taxes and spending LESS is the correct formula to turn an ailing economy around. Proof is in the Regan pudding. Obama and many of the worlds liberal leaders just don't get it, all they want is POWER."

#45 AlyBlack, St. Ronnie ended up having to raise taxes. So spare us "liberals". Nothing ever "trickled down". They just lined their pockets. Turn off Rush and get actual facts.

I think we need MENTAL STIMULUS to recover. Obama could encourage the whole nation to get involved in continuous mental stimulation with career traing and education.

This has been referred to as: EduConomy, linking education and economy. See: W-WIN.com for EduConomy ideas. Also see my short blog: EconomyWiseUp.com .

Recovery need sources of HOPE. As Jesse Jackson put it: Keep hope alive. Martin Luther King said he had a DREAM. One Senator Obama had an Audacity of Hope. Now, we need hope to revive the economy.

I hope that Obama will inject that spirit of hope, by encouraging EduConomy, right now ... Harry@RochesterNY
Yes Karl, #84.  Let's see what New Jersey's education system looks like in 10 years.  I'm sure Snooki and The Situation will need replacements on their reality show.

The world is embarking on a path to a 2nd Great Depression, and the hopes to the contrary seem wishful.

It is exactly this simple -- who will buy to make up for everyone trying to cut spending at the same time? Answer: no nation will step up here, and the world economy is setting up for a sharp leg downwards, and that move will naturally have it's own feedback/momentum.

findingourdream.blogspot.com

If this idiotic administration would call a moritorium on their myriad of grandiose initiatives, a very nervous America might possibly come out of hiding and begin hiring, investing and spending again!

Nobody can figure out what these quasi-academics plan to come up with next.

It's time to face reality.

Corporations, in their eagerness to cut wages, forgot that their employees are also their customers. If their wages go down, they'll have less money to spend on goods and services.

The day of reckoning was delayed at first by having wives join the workforce and then by borrowing against bubble home values.

Now there are no more tricks in the hat. Government spending to make up for lack of consumer spending can only last so long and only another delay tactic if consumer spending isn't coming back anyway.

Thirty years of shipping jobs to other countries so CEOs can make a bigger bonuses has come back to bite us in the derriere.

Welcome to the new reality of high unemployment, millions living in the street, coming civil unrest and possibly a revolution to replace a government that has abandoned the people for corporate interests.
